sp.p: He takes it with a grain of salt!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: But isn't he going to bring a counter suit?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: I hope not. I am an old-fashioned woman and don't believe in divorce!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Really! But then you're not married!

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: What is the reason for so much divorce nowadays?

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Marriage is the principal one.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I don't believe in divorce, either.

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: My dear, no woman married to as handsome a man as Mr. Sterling would.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: You people are all out of date! More people get divorced nowadays than get married.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Too many people do — that's the trouble. I meant what I said when I was married — "for better, for worse, till death us do part." — What is the opera Monday?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Something of Wagner's. He's a Dodo bird! Bores me to death! Not catchy enough music for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: You'd adore him if you went to Bayreuth. Which was that opera, Clara, we heard at Bayreuth last summer? Was it Faust or Lohengrin! They play those two so much here I'm always getting them mixed!

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: Wagner didn't write Faust!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Didn't he? I thought he had; he's written so many operas the last few seasons!

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: I like Tannhäuser , because as soon as you hear the "twinkle, twinkle, little stars" song, you can cheer up and think of your wraps and fur boots.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: My favorite operas are San Toy and the Roger Brothers , though I saw Florodora thirty-six times!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Mother would have gone with you every one of those thirty-six Florodora times. She's not really fond of music.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Not fond of music! Didn't I have an opera box for four years?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Why doesn't Conned make some arrangement with Weber and Fields and introduce their chorus into Faust and Carmen ?

sp.speaker: Dr. Steinhart .
sp.p:
Great idea!
[ To Miss Godesby .]
Did you get a lot of jolly presents?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Not half bad, especially two fine French bulls!

div.stage: All are laughing and talking together .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: What did you get, Mr. Warden?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Three copies of "David Harum," two umbrellas, and a cigar case too short for my cigars.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Give it to me for cigarettes.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: It's too long for cigarettes. Then I had something that's either a mouchoir or a handkerchief case, or for neckties, or shaving papers, or something or other.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Yes, I know, I got one of those, too.

sp.speaker: Dr. Steinhart .
sp.p: So did I!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I must start the women; we are coming back here to arrange a surprise for you men.

div.stage: She nods her head in signal to Sterling , and rises. All rise .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: One moment please. One toast on Christmas night! Ned, give us a toast.

sp.speaker: All the Women .
sp.p:
Oh, yes! A toast!
[ Ad lib .]

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.l: Here's to those whom we love!
And to those who love us!
And to those who love those whom we love
And to those who love those who love us!

sp.speaker: All the Men .
sp.p:
Good! Bravo! Bully toast!
[ Ad lib .]

div.stage: Every one drinks .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
One more toast, Dick.
[ To the others .]
Christmas Day is our boy's birthday.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Surely! a toast to Richard!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Long life to Master Sterling, the best boy in the world, and to all his good friends at this table.

sp.speaker: The Men .
sp.p: Hear! Hear!

div.stage: All the women speak their next speeches at the same time .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Of course! I've dropped my handkerchief.

div.stage: Ned dives under the took for it .

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p:
O dear, my fan!
[ All together ]

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
What a bore! I've dropped a glove!
[ All together ]

div.stage: Steinhart goes under the table for it .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
Both my gloves gone — I'm so sorry!
[ All together ]

div.stage: Godesby goes under the table for them .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p:
Dick, please, I've dropped my smelling bottle.
[ All together ]

div.stage: Trotter and Sterling go under the table for it .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p:
My gloves, please, I'm so sorry!
[ All together ]

div.stage: Mason goes under the table for them .
The speeches of the women are simultaneous, followed by the movements of the men also, all at the same time .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Please don't bother; the servants —

div.stage: Leonard, Jordan , and two extra men start to hunt under the table, too .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Women ought to have everything they own fastened to them with rubberneck elastics.

div.stage: The men, somewhat flustered, all rise with the various articles, and offer them to their respective owners .
All the women thank the men profusely, and apologize at the same time . Sterling takes Mrs. Hunter out at back, followed by all the other couples, all talking . Ruth and Mason lag behind .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.stage: To Blanche , who with Warden waits for Ruth and Mason to pass
sp.p:
I want just a minute with Mr. Mason, Blanche.
[ Blanche and Warden pass out before her . Ruth is alone with Mason . She speaks as if she were carrying on a conversation that had been interrupted. She speaks in a lowered voice, indicating the private nature of what she has to say .]
I sent him imperative word yesterday I must have the bonds. I told him I wanted one to give to his wife for Christmas. He pretends to-day he didn't receive this letter, but he must have.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: This makes the third time there has been some excuse for not giving you the bonds?

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Yes, and this letter he says he didn't get was sent to his office by hand.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: I'll speak to him before I leave.

div.stage: They go out at back .

As they pass out , Jordan stands by the doorway holding the curtains back. The other three men stand stiffly at the Right. As Mason and Ruth go out, the Servants relax and exchange glances, each giving a little laugh out loud, except Jordan . During the following dialogue they empty the table preparatory to arranging the room for the Christmas tree .

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p: Sh! A very dull dinner, not an interesting word spoke.

sp.speaker: First Footman .
sp.p: The widder seemed chipper like!

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: And did you get on to the old lady's rig-out; mourning don't hang very heavy on her shoulders.

div.stage: One chair is moved back .

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p:
Get the coffee.
[ He goes out Right. To Leonard .]
Get the smoking lay-out!

div.stage: Leonard goes out Right and brings back a silver tray laden with cigarettes, cigar boxes, and a burning alcohol lamp .

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: If you ask me, I think she's going to put a bit more on the matrimonial mare if she gets the chance.

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p: It's none of your business. You're Mrs. Sterling's servant now.

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: Good thing, too; it was a happy day for us when they moved in.

sp.speaker: First Footman .
sp.p:
Say, did you see how that young feller over there
[ Motioning to the lower right-hand corner of the table .]
shovelled the food in?

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: And the way he poured down the liquid — regular hog! My arm's tired a-filling of his glass.

div.stage: And he drinks a glass of champagne which has been left untouched by a guest .

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p:
He ain't nobody; he hasn't any money; he was just asked to fill up. He's one of these
yere singing chaps what's asked to pass the time after dinner with a song or two gratis . This dinner'll last him for food for a week!

div.stage: Their manners suddenly change as the men reënter and take seats about the two ends of the table . Sterling, Mason , and Doctor down Left form one group. The other men are in a group between the window and the other end. On entering Sterling speaks .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Jordan, for heaven's sake, give us something to see by! You can't tell which end of your cigar to light in this confounded woman's candle-light. If I had my way, I'd have candelabras made of Welsbachs!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Bright idea, Sterling.

div.stage: Sterling , laughing, joins his group, who laugh gently with him . Jordan turns on the electric light. The servants pass the coffee, liqueurs, and the cigars and cigarettes. Meanwhile the following dialogue takes place, the men beginning to talk at once on their entrance .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Mr. Mason, I'd like to ask your honest opinion on something if you'll give it me.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: This Hudson Electric Company.

sp.speaker: Dr. Steinhart .
sp.p: Oh! Dropped fearfully to-day.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: But that can happen easily with the best thing. To-morrow —

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: To-morrow it will drop to its very bottom!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Sreinhart .
sp.p: Surely, Mr. Mason, the men who floated that are too clever to ruin themselves .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: They're out of it.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Out of it!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: They got out last week quietly.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Mark my words, the day after to-morrow there'll be several foolish people ruined, and not one of the promoters of that company will lose a penny!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I don't believe it!

div.stage: The crowd at the other end of the table, who have been listening to a tale from Trotter , laugh heartily .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I'm no Dodo bird!

div.stage: Warden leaves this group casually and joins the other .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Don't tell me you're in it?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes, I am in it!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Not much?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes, much!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Much what?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Oh, nothing; we were just discussing stocks.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And up there they're discussing Jeffreys and Fitzsimmons.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Listen, Dick, after a lifelong experience in Wall Street, I defy any broker to produce one customer who can show a profit after three consecutive years of speculation.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Oh, you're too conservative; nothing venture, nothing have. Excuse me, I think Jeffreys and Fitzsimmons more amusing topics. Come along.

div.stage: Sterling and Dr. Steinhart join the other group Right .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: You're Sterling's broker.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, not for over a year.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Then you can't tell me how deep he is in this Hudson Electric swindle?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Is he in it at all?

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Yes, he says, deep.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I suspected it yesterday.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: But what with — his wife's money?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: That went fourteen months ago. I put him on his feet then, gave him some tips that enabled him to take this house with her mother, so that with his regular law business he ought to have done very well, but his living could not leave one cent over to speculate with.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Good God!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I know what you're afraid of.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
Yes. The reason I'm no longer
his broker is he was ashamed to let me know about his dealings.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: But you don't mean you think he'd actually steal!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: His aunt's money? Why not? He did his wife's!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Does he handle any one else's affairs?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I know he takes care of that Godesby woman's property.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: And she wouldn't hold her tongue if a crash came!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Not for a minute! Is Miss Hunter suspicious?

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Yes. Does Sterling realize that to-morrow he will most probably be a ruined cheat?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: If he made up his mind to-night it was all up with him, he might do — what?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Run away with whatever money he has left, or kill himself. I don't know if he's enough of a coward for that or not. There's one hold on him — he loves his wife.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Which will make him all the more ashamed of discovery. Do you believe she suspects?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Not a bit. She loves him too dearly.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Can we do anything?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Nothing but watch him closely till the people Then force him to make a clean breast of it, so we can all know where we stand; how we can best protect his aunt from ruin and his wife and boy from public disgrace.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: He is watching us.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
He knows I know him; we must be careful. He's coming toward us.
[ He then speaks in a different tone, but no louder .]
You're certain of the trustworthiness of your information?

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p:
Absolutely. Every man left in that concern will be ruined before the 'Change closes after to-morrow.
[ Sterling has joined them in time to hear the end of Mason's speech . Mason continues .]
I am telling Warden what I told you about the Hudson Electric Company.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Can't you talk of something pleasanter?

div.stage: Blanche reënters at back. On her entrance all the men rise. The servants finish preparing the room for the tree .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I'm very sorry — I really can't let you men stay here any longer.

sp.speaker: All the Men .
sp.p:
Why not? How's that?
[ Ad lib .]

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
You know we want to get this room ready for Santa Claus! Dick!
[ She goes to her husband. All the men go out at back in a group led by Warden and Mason . They are all talking and laughing . Blanche is left alone with her husband .]
What is this Aunt Ruth has been telling me about not being able to get some bonds from you?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Oh, nothing. I forgot to send them up to her, that's all.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: But she says she sent three times.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: One time too late to get into the vault; and the other, her letter was mislaid — I mean not given to me.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: You haven't broken your word to me?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: What if I had?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I would let the law take its course.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: You must love me very little.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I live with you. First you robbed me of my respect for you; then you dried up my heart with neglect.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: And our boy?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Your blood runs in his veins; your shame and disgrace would be a fearful warning to him. It might kill me; but never mind, if it saved him .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Oh, well, I haven't broken my word! So you needn't worry. I've been honest enough.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: With a long sigh of relief
sp.p: Oh! I hope so!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: The men are in the drawing-room — shall we come here?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Yes, we'll bring the others, mother. Come, Dick.

div.stage: She goes out with Mrs. Hunter at back .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.stage: Goes to door Right, opens it, and calls .]
sp.p: Leonard!

div.stage: Leonard enters Right .

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: Yes, sir?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Go up to my library at the top of the house, get a railroad guide you will find there, and bring it down and put it on the table in the hall just outside the drawing-room door.

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Then go to my room and pack my bag and dressing case. Do you understand?

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: Yes, sir.

div.stage: The women are heard singing "Follow the Man from Cook's," and gradually coming nearer .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Be quick, and say nothing to any one.

sp.speaker: Leonard .
sp.p: Yes, sir.

div.stage: He goes out quickly Right . Sterling goes up stage and stands beside the door at back as the women dance in, singing "Follow the Man from Cook's." They are led by Clara , with Mrs. Hunter on the end . Blanche and Ruth follow alone, not dancing. The others dance around the chairs and Clara jumps on and off one of them; this stops the rest, who balk at it . Sterling goes out at back. The Servants enter Right .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: I don't care for this dinner party at all. The women are all the time being chased away from the men! I prefer being with Mr. Trotter. Don't you, mama?

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: He doesn't seem able to give a dinner party any more without you to chaperone, Mrs. Hunter.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Mother, how can you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Oh, I don't know as it's chaperoning! I like Mr. Trotter very much.

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: But he's such a little cad. I tried to give him a lift, but he was too heavy for me.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Oh, well, you ought just to pretend it's the money in his pocket makes him so heavy; then you'd find him dead easy.

div.stage: Meanwhile the Servants have arranged the table, taken out the extra leaves and made it square, and left the room. They now reënter, bringing in a gorgeously decorated and lighted Christmas tree. There is at once a loud chorus of delighted approval from the women. The Servants place the tree in the centre of the table. The women who are sitting rise and come near to examine the tree .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: What a beautiful tree, Blanche!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
The boy is to have it to-morrow morning — it's really his tree!
[ Tompson brings in a large basket containing seven small stockings and six small boys' socks — very small stockings and very small socks. They are made of bright and different colors and are stuffed into absurd, bulgy shapes .]
There's a name on each one. Come along now!

div.stage: Taking out a little sock. The women crowd around the basket and each hangs a sock on the tree , Miss Godesby and Clara standing on chairs .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.stage: Reading the name on her sock
sp.p: Oh! mine's for Mr. Mason. What's in it, Blanche?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I really can't tell you. I asked the clerk where I bought it what it was for, and he said he didn't know; it was a "Christmas present."

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, I know the kind! Mine's for Howard Godesby. What's his present?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: A silver golf marker.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: But he doesn't play golf!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Well, he ought to; it'll keep him young.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: It will be all right, anyway, Julia! You can give it away to some one next Christmas.

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: What's in Mr. Trotter's?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Oh, that present has almost been my death! Men are so hard to find things for! I had put in a gold pencil for his key chain, but to-night while we were eating our oysters, I saw him show a beauty that his mother had given him this morning! So I whispered to Jordan between the soup and fish to change Mr. Ryder's name to Mr. Trotter's stocking, and put Mr. Trotter's name on the one that had a cigarette case in it. I sneaked a message down to Dick on my dinner card — was it all right? — and he sent back word during the game that Trotter only smoked cigars; so before the ices were passed I shuffled Mr. Trotter's and Mr. Mason's names, — I'd given Mason the cigar case; — and just as Jordan signalled to me the
transfer had been successfully effected, I heard Trotter casually observe he'd been obliged to give up smoking entirely — doctor's orders!

div.stage: They laugh punctiliously, rather bored by Blanche's long account .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Isn't the tree stunning?

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: It makes the table look like one of Mr. Trotter's "informal little dinners."

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: They say he has one of those men who arrange shop windows decorate his dinner table for him!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: The only time I ever dined with him I was really ashamed to go home with my dinner favor — it was so gorgeous! And there were such big bunches of violets in the finger bowls there wasn't room for your little finger.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
You never saw such a lot of
decoration! The game have ribbon garters on their legs, and even the raw oysters wear corsage bouquets!
[ To Mrs. Hunter .]
I hope you don't mind what we're saying, Mrs. Hunter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p:
I must say I do mind very much. —
[ A pause .]
— because —
[ A second pause .]
— well, I am going to marry Mr. Trotter —
[ All, not believing her, laugh merrily .]
You are all very rude!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Not on the level! Not Trotter!

sp.speaker: Miss Sillerton .
sp.p: Not really!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No, no, of course not!

div.stage: She rings bell .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: But I am! And I thought here at my daughter's table, among my own friends (I was allowed to name the guests to-night), I could count on good wishes and congratulations.

div.stage: There is a dead silence
The musicians, a band of Neapolitan players, enter and take their places in a recess at Left .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
You may play.
[ To Jordan , who has brought in the Neapolitans .]
We are ready, Jordan.

div.stage: Jordan goes out at back .
Ruth goes to Blanche .
The guitars and mandolins begin a popular song .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, well, Mrs. Hunter, we were only codding! There's lots of good in Trotter, and I'm sure you'll bring it out. Good luck!

div.stage: Shaking her hand .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: You won't allow this!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Certainly not.
[ Blanche crosses to her mother and they go to one side together; Blanche speaks in a lowered voice .]
You've amazed and
shocked me! I will not tolerate such a thing; we'll talk it over to-night.

div.stage: She leaves her and returns to her guests , Mrs. Hunter standing where she is left, biting her lips and almost crying with rage and mortification .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.stage: Before the musicians, to Blanche as she joins her
sp.p: I'm crazy about these men, Mrs. Sterling; they play so awfully well — especially that one with the lovely legs!

div.stage: Jordan pulls aside the curtains at back and all the men reënter except Warden . They all join hands and dance around the tree, singing with the musicians; they break, and go up to a side table, where everything to drink is displayed . Warden enters at this moment and motions to Mason and leads him down stage .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: There was a railway guide in the hall — that's what he went there for; he's going to run away to-night .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: How'll we prevent it?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: First, we must break up this party!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
I haven't quite thought yet. Go back to the others; send Jordan to me; don't lose sight of Dick. Jordan!
[ He takes him aside .]
I want you to go out of this room for a minute, pretend to go upstairs, then come back and tell Mrs. Sterling, loud enough for the others to hear you, that Master Richard is very ill, and say the maid is frightened.

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Do as I tell you. I am responsible for whatever happens.

div.stage: Jordan goes out at back. The men and women are laughing and talking about the sideboard .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Come now, everybody! Let's have the presents. Dick, you know you are to be Santa Claus.

div.stage: Sterling looks nervously at his watch .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p:
Just a minute, dear! Ned!
[ Takes Warden to one side. The women move about the tree, hunting for their own names on the stockings on the table at the foot of the tree .]
Ned, I've been suddenly called out of town on business — must catch the eleven-twenty train. I don't want to break up the party, so you empty the tree, and when the time comes for me to go, I'll slip out.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And when your guests go?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Oh, then you can explain for me.

div.stage: Jordan enters at back .

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p: Beg pardon, madam, but Master Richard is very ill.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Richard!

sp.speaker: Jordan .
sp.p: Yes, ma'am, and Droves is very frightened, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Richard ill?

div.stage: All give exclamations of surprise and regret and sympathy .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: My little boy ill? Excuse me, I must go to him.

div.stage: She hurries out at back . Ruth speaks to the musicians, who stop playing .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: My boy ill — why, I can't — I can't —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: "Can't" what?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: How can I go away?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Surely you won't let business take you away from your boy who may be dying.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No! I won't got I'll face it out! I can't leave my boy like this —

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: I'm going to take these women away; tell Blanche not to give them a thought. Their evening up to now has been charming.

div.stage: During Ruth's speech , Warden has spoken aside with Mason .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Don't let Miss Hunter go.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Come to the drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: I was crazy to see what was in my stocking.

div.stage: All pass out talking, expressing conventional sympathy on account of Richard , but evidently resenting the breaking up of the party . Sterling and Warden are left alone in the room . Sterling moves to go up to back; Warden interrupts him .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: To my boy and my wife.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Wait a minute; I want to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Speak to me later; I can't wait now.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Jordan!
[ She enters, excited, half hysterical .]
Jordan! Where is Jordan? It was a lie! What did he mean? Richard is sleeping sweetly. The maid knows nothing of being alarmed! Where is Jordan?

div.stage: She starts to go toward the door Right .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Mrs. Sterling, he had nothing to do with it! I told Jordan to say what he said.

div.stage: Blanche turns and looks at Warden in astonishment .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Forgive me for so cruelly alarming you; it was the only way I could think of for getting rid at once of your guests!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: You'll interfere once too often in the affairs of this house.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: But what excuse can you make, Mr. Warden?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Will you be so good as to ask Miss Hunter and Mr. Mason to come here? They will explain what I have done, partly, and your husband will tell you the rest when you come back.

div.stage: Sterling sneers aloud .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I don't understand, I don't understand.

div.stage: She goes out at back .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Well, I do understand, at least enough.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good! That spares me a very disagreeable speech.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No, it doesn't! Come out with it! What is it you want? What is it you've found out?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: From betraying a trust, you've come, in less than two years, to an outright embezzlement.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Speak out — give us facts!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You've stolen your aunt's fortune.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Prove that!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: It's her money that's lost in the Hudson Electric Company!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Prove it !

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Easy enough, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: You've got to excuse your action to-night or be kicked out of my house!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Isn't what I say the truth?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No! And now get out!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I'll not leave this house till it's too late for you to take that eleven-twenty.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes, you will and mighty —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, I'll not!

div.stage: He is interrupted by the entrance of Blanche, Ruth , and Mason .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I hope you forgive me now —

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: You did right; I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Blanche — without hearing a word from me!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No, I've come now to hear what you have to say.

div.stage: A deep-toned clock strikes eleven . Sterling , at the second stroke, takes out his watch with a hurried movement .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Eleven o'clock.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I wish Warden to leave the room.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: And I wish him to stay.

div.stage: A short pause .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Well, of what am I accused?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Nobody wants to accuse you. We want you to make a clean breast of it.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Don't you talk to me; let my wife do the talking if you want me to answer.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Sit down, Aunt Ruth.
[ Ruth sits by the table , Warden stands at back . Sterling stands at Right and Blanche and Mason sit near the centre .]
Aunt Ruth asks you to give her a true account of her trust in you. Mr. Mason is here as her friend and my father's.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I haven't said I betrayed her trust. I told her she should have the bonds she wants to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
But will she? That's what I want to know. I ask you if you haven't her bonds, to tell us here now, — tell us , who have been and must be still the best friends, perhaps the only friends, you can have. Tell us where we all stand — are we the only ones to suffer or are there others who will perhaps be less generous in their treatment of you? Tell us now while there is time perhaps to save us from public scandal, from the disgrace which would stamp your wife as the wife of a thief, and send your boy out into the world
the son of a convict cheat.
[ She breaks down, but in a moment controls herself. There is no answer . Sterling sinks into a chair, his arms on the table, his head on his arms. A moment's silence .]
You love me — I know that. I appeal to your love; let your love of me persuade you to do what I ask. I ask it for your sake and for mine! Tell us here the truth now — it will spare me much to-morrow, perhaps — me whom you love — for love of me —

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I'm afraid I'll lose you —

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No, I'll promise to stand by you if you'll only tell us all the Ruth.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I'll tell you , but not now — not before all these others.

div.stage: Blanche looks up questioningly to Mason. Mason shakes his head .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: It must be now , Dick.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No! no! I can't look you in the face and tell it! Let me tell it to you alone , later, in the dark.

div.stage: Blanche looks up questioningly to Mason . He shakes his head .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: It must be now.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No, no, I'm too ashamed, I can't face you; in the dark I'll make a clean breast of it — let me tell you in the dark.

div.stage: Warden moves and puts his hand on the electric-light button beside the doorway at back .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: In the dark , then, tell it!

div.stage: He presses the button and all the lights go out. The stage is in complete darkness; only the voices are heard from the different places in which the actors are last seen .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Remember, to help you
to help ourselves, we must know everything. Go on.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: It began fourteen months ago, after Ned Warden put me on my feet; I got a little ahead — why not get way ahead? There were plenty of men around me making their fortunes! I wanted to equal them — climb as high as they; it seemed easy enough for them, and luck had begun to come my way. We're all climbers of some sort in this world. I was a climber after wealth and everything it brings —

div.stage: He stops a moment .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: Her voice comes throbbing with pathetic emotion through the darkness
sp.p: And I after happiness and all it brings.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.stage: Deeply moved, his voice trembles for a moment, but only for a moment
sp.p:
Don't, Blanche, or I can't finish. Well, I borrowed on some of
Aunt Ruth's bonds and speculated — I made a hundred thousand in a week! I put back the bonds. But it had been so easy! I could see those bonds grinning at me through the iron side of the vault box. They seemed to smile and beckon, to beg me to take them out into the air again! They grew to be like living things to me, servants of mine to get me gold — and finally I determined to make one bigger coup than ever! I took Aunt Ruth's bonds out and all the money available in my trust, and put it all into this new company! It seemed so safe. I stood to be a prince among the richest! And, for a day or so, I've known nothing short of a miracle could save me from being wanted by the police! To-night I gave up even the miracle. That's all. It's no use saying I'm sorry.

div.stage: A moment's pause .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Have others suffered besides Miss Hunter?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: There is some money of Aunt Ruth's left — stock I couldn't transfer. But I used the money of others — Miss Godesby and Ryder's.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Miss Ruth, a large part of your fortune is gone, used unlawfully by this man. Will you resort to the law?

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: In a voice broken with emotion and gratitude
sp.p: Aunt Ruth!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: We can't hope Miss Godesby and Ryder will be as lenient! You must go to them in the morning — tell them everything, put yourself at their mercy, ask for time and their silence.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Never! I couldn't do it

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: It is the only honorable way out of your dishonorable action — the least you can do!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Confess to their faces, and probably to no good? Eat the dust at their feet, and most likely be clapped into prison for it? No, thank you!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Suppose I went to them?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: No! Why should you!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes! Why not? They might keep silent for her!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I would do it for my boy's sake. Yes, I'll go.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes! You go, Blanche.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: No, you shan't go — you shan't humiliate yourself in his place!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Certainly not; and if your husband is willing, we are not willing! He must go.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: But if he won't?

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: He must!

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: You must demand his going, Blanche, and I demand it, too, as something due to me.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Very well. I demand it. Will you go?

div.stage: A moment's silence .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
Why don't you speak?
[ He presses the electric button and all the lights come on . Sterling is at the doorway at back, about to steal out. There is an exclamation aloud from all of surprise and disgust. The clock strikes the quarter; Warden catches hold of Sterling's arm .]
What's your hurry, Dick? There goes the quarter hour; you could never catch the eleven-twenty.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Damn you!

div.stage: Facing Warden squarely, as
The Curtain Falls Quickly

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: At "The Hermitage," on the Bronx River, the next afternoon. The house is on the Left, and on the Right and at the back are the green lattice arches. Snow lies thick everywhere, on the benches at the Right and on the little iron table beside it, on the swing between two trees at the Right, in the red boxes of dead shrubs, on the rocks and dried grass of a "rookery" in the centre, and on the branches of the trees . Clara comes out from the house, followed by Trotter .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
Come on and let mama rest awhile — naturally she's excited and tired out, being married so suddenly and away from home.
[ She stops beside the swing, taking held of its side rope with her hand .]
It isn't every mother who can elope without her oldest child's consent and have her youngest daughter for a bridesmaid.

div.stage: Laughing .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I hope Mrs. Sterling will forgive me. Perhaps she will when she sees how my money can help your mother and me to get right in with all the smarties!

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Oh, don't you be too sure about your getting in; it isn't as easy as the papers say! But, anyway, that wouldn't make any difference to Blanche. She was never a climber like mama and me. I suppose that's why she is asked to all sorts of houses through Aunt Ruth that wouldn't let mama and me even leave our cards on the butler!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I thought your mother could go anywhere she liked.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Oh, no, she couldn't! if she made you think that, it was only a jolly! Blanche is the only one of us who really went everywhere. Come along, "Poppa" give me a swing! I haven't had one for years!

div.stage: She sweeps off the snow from the seat of the swing with her hand .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Your mother certainly did represent —

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Oh, well, now don't blame mama! She couldn't help herself; she always thought you dreadfully handsome! Swing me!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I don't care, anyway. I'm deucedly proud of your mother, — I mean of my wife , — and I'd just as lief throw up the whole society business and go off and live happily by ourselves.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
O dear! I think mama would find
that awfully dull. Go on, swing me!
[ Trotter swings her .]
Of course, you'll find mama a little different when you see her all the time. You really won't see much more of her, though, than you do now. She doesn't get up till noon, and has her masseuse for an hour every morning, her manicure and her mental science visitor every other day, and her face steamed three times a week! She has to lie down a lot, too, but you mustn't mind that; you must remember she isn't our age!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: She suits me!

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
That's just what I feel! You'll take care of her, and me, too, all our lives, and that's what makes me so happy. I'm full of plans! We'll go abroad soon and stay two years.
[ He has stopped swinging her .]
Go on, swing me!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p:
Say! if you think you are going to run me and the whole
family, you're a Dodo bird! Remember that you're my daughter; you must wait a little it you want to be a mother-in-law.

div.stage: Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance, coming nearer .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Good gracious! If you ask me , I think mama has got her hands full. What's become of Miss Godesby and her brother?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: When you went upstairs with your mother, they went down the road.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: You know originally the idea was I was to marry you.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Really —

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Yes, and mama cut me out.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Oh, well, it can't be helped; we can't marry everybody.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
Somebody else
arriving! That's queer — nobody comes here in the winter; that's why we chose it, because it would be quiet! Let's play this game.

div.stage: Going to an iron frog on a box which stands near the house .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Perhaps it's Mrs. Sterling.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
No; if she was coming at all, she'd have come in time for the wedding.
[ She takes up the disks which lie beside the frog .]
I should hate to get married like you and mama — no splurge and no presents! Why, the presents'd be half the fun! And think of all those you and she've given in your life, and have lost now a good chance of getting back.

div.stage: Throws a disk into the frog's open mouth .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I'll give your mother all the presents she wants. I can afford it; I don't want anybody to give us anything!

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
You talk like Jess!
[ Throws another disk .]
You know Jess earns her own living. She goes around to smart women's houses answering their invitations and letters for 'em. She calls it being a visiting secretary, but I tell her she's a co-respon-dent!

div.stage: Throws a disk .
Warden and Mason enter from behind the house quickly, with a manner of suppressed excitement. They are surprised to find Clara and Trotter .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Why, here they are!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: No, only Miss Clara and Trotter.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Lucky I met you — you must take me back in your sleigh.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Yes, the riding's beastly.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Hello! I say, were you invited?

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Merry Christmas!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: We came to see the Godesbys.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: They've gone down the road.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Sterling isn't here, is he?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: No, haven't seen him.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Do you know why we're here?

div.stage: Mason and Warden are embarrassed .

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Yes — er — er — a — many happy returns, Mr. Trotter.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: It's a great day for me, Mr. Mason!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Wish you joy, Trotter!

div.stage: Embarrassed and not going near him . Trotter rushes eagerly to him and grasps his hand warmly .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Thank you, old man! I say! Thank you!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: Miss Clara, would you do me the great favor of going down the road and hurrying the Godesbys back if you see them?

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Yes, I don't mind; come along, Trotty!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You must excuse Trotter. I want a talk with him if he will give me five minutes.

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Oh, certainly.

div.stage: She goes out Left behind the house .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Will you see Mrs. Hunter?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mrs. Trotter!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
I beg yours.
[ To Mason .]
See Mrs. Trotter.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: You're going to ask him to go on Dick's note for Ryder?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: You're a wonder! As if he would!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Somebody must , and there's nobody else. That boy and that mother have got to be saved!

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: I'm sorry my name's no good for us.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And mine mustn't be used.

sp.speaker: Mason .
sp.p: No, indeed! The minute that was done, there'd be a new complication, and more trouble would tumble down on Mrs. Sterling's head. Good luck.

div.stage: Shakes his hand and enters the house .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: What's up? You haven't come to kick about my wedding, have you? I wouldn't stand for that, you know!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: It's not that, Mr. Trotter. Your wife's son-in-law, Sterling, has turned out a blackguard; he has had intrusted to him Miss Ruth Hunter's money and several other people's, and he's used it all for speculation of his own.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Then he's a damned thief!

div.stage: He sits on the bench with the manner that he has settled the subject .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: So he is, and he's ruined.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Well, prison is the place for him .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: We won't argue that, but how about his family — they get punished for what he has done; they must share his disgrace.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Oh, well, my wife is out of all that now — she's Mrs. Trotter .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes, but her own daughter suffers.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: She isn't very chummy with her classy eldest daughter.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Never mind that; you know without my telling you that Mrs. Sterling is a fine woman.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: She's always snubbed me right and left, but, by George, I must own she is a fine woman.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
That's right!
[ Clapping him on the back and putting his arm around his shoulder .]
Look here — help us save her!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Indorse a note of Sterling's to give Ryder to keep him quiet.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: I'd have to ask my wife.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No! Don't start off like that! Keep the reins in your own hands at the very beginning, — make her realize from this very day that you're raised up on the cushion beside her; that she's sitting lower down admiring the scenery, while you do the driving through life!

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Ha! I guess you're right. Box seat and reins are good enough for me!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good boy! Then we can count on you to sign this note?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Where's my security?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I can get you security if you want it.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Of course I want it! And I say, where are you? Why aren't you in it?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: There are reasons why my name had better not appear; you are in the family. But I'll tell you what I'll do, Trotter; I'll secure you with a note of my own — only you must keep it dark; you mustn't even let Mason know.

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: All right, perhaps I'm a Dodo bird, but I'll do it. Say, I seem to have married a good many of this classy family!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Trotter, no one's done you justice! And, by George! you deserve a better fate — er — I mean — my best wishes on your wedding day.

div.stage: Trotter shakes his hand delightedly .

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p: Great day for me! What I wanted was style and position, and some one classy who would know how to spend my money for me!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Well, you've got that, surely!

div.stage: Clara comes back from the house .

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p:
The Godesbys are coming. Trotter,
there's skating on the river near here, and they've skates in the house — don't you want a spin?

sp.speaker: Trotter .
sp.p:
Yes, I don't mind — if my wife doesn't need me!
[ Clara laughs as Godesby and Miss Godesby enter from behind the house . Trotter meets them, with Clara on his arm .]
Excuse us for a little while!

sp.speaker: Clara .
sp.p: Poppa and I're going skating!

div.stage: They go out Left .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Hello, Warden.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good morning, Miss Godesby.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: How are you, Godesby? I've come on a matter most serious, most urgent — something very painful.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: What is it?

div.stage: Comes forward .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Both of you trusted Dick Sterling.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: What's he done?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Misused your funds.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: How d'you mean?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I mean that the money you intrusted to him is gone, and I've come to make a proposition to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Gone?

div.stage: Godesby and Miss Godesby are aghast. A second's silence, during which Godesby and Miss Godesby look at each other, then back at Warden .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Do you mean to say —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: The money is gone , every penny of it, and I want you to accept a note from Sterling to cover the amount.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I can't grasp it!

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Where is Sterling? Why didn't he come?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: He was ashamed.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: I should hope so!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Several of us are going to stick by him; we'll manage to put him on his feet again, and we want you to accept his note.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Accept his note?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: On what security?

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: You'll do nothing of the sort, Julia!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I'll see him where he belongs, in State's Prison, first!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: That wouldn't bring you back your money.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Neither will his note!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: If I get it indorsed?

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Likely!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Rather!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I want your silence to keep it from the public for the family's sake. I've secured a satisfactory indorser for a note to satisfy Ryder's claim.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Why didn't you give him to me instead of Ryder?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I felt you would be willing, out of friendship —

div.stage: There are sleigh-bells in the distance, coming nearer .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Huh! you must take me for an idiot!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Out of friendship for his wife.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Blanche Sterling! I never could bear her! She's always treated me like the dirt under her feet!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You dined with her last night.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
That was to please her mother.
No, if my money's gone, Sterling's got to suffer, and the one slight consolation I shall have will be that Blanche Sterling will have to come off her high horse.

div.stage: The sleigh-bells stop .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Ten to one if you agree to sign this note —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And keep silent.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, yes, of course, the next morning when I wake up Sterling will be gone! Nobody knows where!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I've had it out with Sterling! I am here as his representative. I give you my word of honor Sterling will not run away. It is under such an understanding with him that I am pleading his case in his stead. He will stay here and work till he has paid you back, every cent.

div.stage: Jessica enters hurriedly from the house .

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: Mr. Warden, Mr. Warden, Dick has gone!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Sterling? Gone?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Gone?

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: That's good!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Don't be a fool, Godesby. How do you mean "gone," Miss Hunter?

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: I don't altogether know. While I was out this morning, Blanche received a message from mother saying she'd been —

div.stage: She hesitates, looking toward Godesby and Miss Godesby .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: They know. They're your mother's guests here.

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p:
She told Blanche they would be glad to have her here at one o'clock for breakfast. Blanche ordered the sleigh at once and went away, leaving word for me I was
to open any message which might come for her.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Has she been here?

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: No, no!

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: No, they say not. She probably went first to Aunt Ruth's. Before I got back, Dick, who'd been out —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: He was at my house.

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: Yes. He came back, questioned Jordan as to where Blanche was, went upstairs, and then went away again, leaving a note for Blanche, which I found when I came home —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: It simply said, "Good-by. Dick."

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: He's taken a train! He's cleared out!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Do you know if he took a bag or anything with him?

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: No, he took nothing of that sort. Jordan went into his room and found a drawer open and empty, a drawer in which Dick kept — a pistol! —

div.stage: She drops her voice almost to a whisper .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good God, he's shot himself!

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: Perhaps not — he left the house.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes, if he were really determined to shoot himself, why wouldn't he have done it there in his own room?

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: What can we do? What can we do?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I'll get Mr. Mason; he's with your mother; he must go back to town at once.

div.stage: Going to the house .

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: He can go with me; I'd better be at the house. Some one must be there.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good!

div.stage: He goes into the house .
Miss Godesby and her brother ignore and apparently forget the presence of Jessica in their excitement. They both speak and move excitedly .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I ought to have suspected something when Sterling told me he was getting ten per cent for my money, — the blackguard!

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: I always told you you were a fool not to take care of your money yourself! You know more about business than most men.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I didn't want to be bothered; besides, there was always something very attractive about Sterling. I don't mind telling you that if he had fallen in love with me instead of the stiff-necked woman he married, I'd have tumbled over myself to get him.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: How do you feel about him now?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Now! Thank God, I'm saved such a waking up! It's going to make a big difference with my income, Howard! I wonder if his wife knew he was crooked! I'll bet you she's got a pot of money stowed away all right in her own name.

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.stage: Who can bear no more, interrupts .]
sp.p: Please — please! Remember that you're speaking of my sister and that every word you are saying cuts through me like a knife.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I beg your pardon; I ought to have thought. I like and respect you, Jess, and I've been very rude.

sp.speaker: Jessica .
sp.p: You've been more than that; you've been cruelly unjust to Blanche in all that you've said!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
Perhaps I have, but I don't
feel in a very generous mood; I've some excuse — so please forgive me.

div.stage: Warden reënters Left .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Mason is waiting for you with the sleigh. He's going first to my house. Dick may have gone back there to hear the result of my interview with Ryder, — then Mason'll try his own house and Sterling's club.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: The police are the best men to find Sterling, whatever's happened.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
You wait a minute with me; I haven't finished with you yet.
[ To Jessica .]
I'll stay here for your sister, in case she comes.

div.stage: Jessica goes out Left .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Don't you give in!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
Not for a minute!
[ To Warden .]
Don't you think, under the circumstances, the wedding breakfast had better be called off, and my brother and I go back to town?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Not till you've given me your promise, both of you, that you will keep silent about the embezzlement of your bonds for the sake of Mrs. Sterling and her son.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Huh!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: For the sake of her mother, who is your friend.

div.stage: Sleigh-bells start up loud and die off quickly; Jessica has gone .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
Oh, come, you know what sort of friends we are, — for the amusement we can get out of each other. This is the case, — I trusted this man with my affairs. He was very attractive — I don't deny that; business with Dick Sterling became more or less of a pleasure — but that
doesn't cut any ice with me; he's stolen my money. To put it plainly, he's a common thief, and he ought to be punished; why should he go scot free and a lot of others not? You know perfectly well his note wouldn't be worth the paper it was written on; and, anyway, if he hasn't gone and sneaked out of the world, I won't lift my little finger to keep him from the punishment he deserves!

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Good for you, Julia!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Don't you put your oar in, Godesby; just let this matter rest between your sister and me! She's always been known as the best man in your family.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: You don't choose a very conciliatory way of bringing us around!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
I'm not choosing any way at all; I'm striking right out from the shoulder. There
isn't time for beating round the bush! I'm pleading for the good name and honorable position of a perfectly innocent, a fine, woman, and for the reputation and unimpeded career of her son! And I make that appeal as man to man and woman!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I have nothing to do with any one in this matter but Sterling himself, who has robbed me, and I'll gladly see him suffer for it!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
Now look here, Miss Godesby, you belong to a pretty tough crowd in society, but I know at heart you're not a bad sort! What good will it do you? Granted even that you don't care for Mrs. Sterling, still don't tell me you're the kind of woman to take a cruel pleasure in seeing another woman suffer! I wouldn't believe it! You're not one of those catty creatures! You're a clever woman, and I don't doubt you can be a pretty
hard one, too, at times; but you're just — that's the point now — you're JUST —

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Exactly! I'm just, an eye for an eye! Sterling is a thief, let him get the deserts of one!

div.stage: She sits on the bench determinedly .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
But you can't look at only one side! You can't shut your eyes to his wife's suffering, too, and she doesn't deserve it! Neither does her boy deserve to share his disgrace.
[ He sits beside her .]
Why, you have it in your power to handicap that boy through his whole life by publishing his father a criminal; or you can give that boy a fair show to prove himself more his mother's son than his father's, and to live an honest — who knows — perhaps a noble life!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I refuse to accept such a responsibility. Ryder —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Ryder's word is given to be silent.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Well, that's his lookout.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You'll have many a heart wrench, I'll bet you! You'll have to run across the results of the harm you do to Mrs. Sterling and Richard day in and day out, year after year! I don't believe you realize what it means! Why, I know you can't bear to see a dog suffer! I met you last week on the street carrying a mangy, crippled brute of a little dog in your arms, afraid lest he'd get into the hands of the vivisectionists, and yet here you'll let a boy and his mother —

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.stage: Interrupts him, struggling against a tiny emotion which he has stirred
sp.p: Stop! Stop! I don't want you working on my feelings that way.

div.stage: She rises and turns from him

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I'm only knocking at the door of your heart. And now because it's opened just a tiny way, you want to shut it in my face again. Will you leave this woman's name fit for her to use? Won't you make that boy's life worth living to him?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.stage: Alter a moment's pause, looks straight into Warden's face
sp.p: I'll tell you what I'll do. Get me some security, some sort of indorsement of Sterling's note —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: If the man's only alive!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: And I'll hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: How long will you give me?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, come, I can't have any monkey business! You must get me my security to-day.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: To-day?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: That's my last word.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Stick to that, Julia!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I shan't try to persuade her against that. Will you leave your sister alone with me a moment. Perhaps you'll see about your sleigh being ready to return to town.

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: I've no objection — if Julia wishes it.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Yes, go on, Howard!

div.stage: Godesby goes out back of house .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.stage: Left alone with Miss Godesby , goes nearer to her
sp.p: Look here! Will you accept my indorsement? Will I be all right?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Then it's settled?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: You don't mean it!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p:
You'd be willing to lose —
[ A revelation comes to her .]
Oh — for Mrs. Sterling! I see!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I wouldn't . I wouldn't see.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: And she's always been blackguarding me for my affairs with men! And all the time —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Don't say any more, please, Miss Godesby! I only wish your brother had said that much instead of you.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: So you're in love with Blanche Sterling?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, come, don't tell a lie about it; that will only make it seem worse.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Well, suppose I were in love with her — what of it?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Nothing; only, my dear Warden, that woman —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
Wait a minute! You've got me in a corner, but knowing half the truth, you mustn't guess the whole. She is even more ignorant of my love for her than you were ten minutes ago!
[ Miss Godesby smiles and makes a little satirical exclamation .]
You don't believe that, but I'll make you. I'm going to tell you something I've never even told myself. I'm going to put you to a big test, because I've got to. Apparently, I can't help myself; but after all, somehow I believe in the human nature in you, and you've got it in your power to help or hurt the woman I love — I say those words aloud for the first time — the woman I love!

div.stage: He has finished his speech in a lowered tone throbbing with controlled feeling .

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: You've never told her?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Never; and you show how little you really know her when you ask that question! She loves her husband.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I'm not so sure about that!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
I am, and I love her . But surely the silent love of a man, like mine, is no insult to a good woman — cannot harm her! A love that is never spoken, not even whispered, can't hurt any one, except, perhaps, the one who loves. You must acknowledge even you have never heard a hint; you showed just now your real surprise at what circumstances revealed to you! I'd die sooner than bring the slightest shadow of a scandal on her, and I've hugged my secret tight. Have you any idea what such a love means? How it grows and grows, its strength shut in, held back,
doubling and redoubling its powers! — its ideality increasing, the passion suppressed , locked up! Good God! I tremble sometimes when I think — suppose some day it should burst out, break my control, master me!
[ A pause .]
And here, now, I've told you; I'm sorry, but I had to for her sake again. Will you help me keep my secret?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Yes, because I believe you.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And Mrs. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: I envy her!

div.stage: Her voice breaks and she turns away from him .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No one is to know I indorse Sterling's note?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: You needn't sign the note; my brother'd have to see it. I'll take your word for the indorsement.

div.stage: She offers him her hand. They shake hands .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: What a brick you are! You know you don't do yourself anything like justice in the world!

div.stage: Godesby reënters Left and after him a Man Servant in ordinary clothes, who passes through the archway at back Centre .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Ready!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You can promise his silence about Sterling?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Oh, yes, he's absolutely dependent upon me.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.stage: To Ned with a forced gaiety
sp.p: Good-by!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good-by.

div.stage: He looks his thanks at her .

sp.speaker: Godesby .
sp.p: Well? What did you do?

sp.speaker: Miss Godesby .
sp.p: Don't worry; I've taken care of myself for many years, and I still feel up to it!

div.stage: They go out Left and at the same time the Servant enters from the archway at back Centre carrying some fire logs in his arms. This Servant speaks with a slight French accent. As he reaches the house , Warden stops him with a question, and the Godesbys' sleigh-bells start up and quickly die away. The sun begins to set .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Have you an empty sitting room?

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: Yes, sair.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Warm?

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: I will soon arrange a fire.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I wish you would, please.

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: Ze big room for ze breakfast is altogether ready and warm; you will be able to go in there now.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, that wouldn't do. It's all right out here for me , only I am expecting a lady.

div.stage: Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance, coming quickly nearer .

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: Yes, sair.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I hear a sleigh coming. If a lady is in it, ask if her name is Mrs. Sterling, and if she says yes, tell her Mr. Warden is here and would like to speak with her a moment before she goes in to Mrs. —

div.stage: He hesitates a second .

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: Trottair?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Servant .
sp.p: Yes, sair.

div.stage: He goes into the house .
The sun grows red, and the colors of sunset creep over the sky during the scene which follows. After a moment the Servant shows Blanche out from the house .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Warden, have you been asked to these funeral baked meats?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, I'll explain why I am here in a few minutes. Only let me ask you first when you last saw your husband?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Early this morning.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: And you have come just now from where?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Aunt Ruth's. Of course you know about my mother? When I heard it I started to come here, but my heart failed me and I turned back to my aunt's. She has persuaded me that I ought to come and put the best face on the matter possible, but it seems as if I'd had now a little more than I can bear!

div.stage: Her voice breaks and her eyes fill with tears .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Shall we go inside?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No, no! Let us stay out in the air; my head would burst in one of these close little rooms. Have you seen mother?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, not yet.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Where is Dick? Did he go to Ryder's?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, but I have some good news to tell you all the same — Ryder has promised silence.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Oh! that's too good, too good to be true! To whom did he promise?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I want you not to ask me that.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I can guess, it was —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No, it was — Mason .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Mr. Mason?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p:
And I've more good news for you.
Mrs. Sterling — the Godesbys , too; they will be silent.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: You're sure?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: We have their word!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Mr. Mason again? —
[ Warden bows his head in assent .]
He was here?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Some time ago, but only for a minute. He didn't stay; he went to find your husband.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
But the Godesbys? I just met them now on the road going back. How could Mr. Mason, if he didn't stay —
[ Warden is embarrassed, and is silent, searching a way out of it .]
Oh, no! no! it wasn't Mr. Mason! I see the whole thing clearly. Dick was too great a coward, and you did it! It was you who won over Ryder! It was you who persuaded the Godesbys! —
[ Warden shakes his head and makes a movement to deny it . Blanche continues speaking, the words rushing to her lips, as her pent-up heart opens and lets all her emotions suddenly free .]
Don't try to deny it; you can't make me believe you! It's to you I owe whatever promise the future has for me! It is you who have given me all the happiness I've had for years. It is you who have watched over, taken care of, me — you , the best friend any woman in this world ever had. It is you now who have saved my boy's honor. It is you who lift the weight off my shoulders, the weight off my heart! You! — you! — you!

div.stage: She sinks sobbing on the bench. It begins to snow very quietly and slowly .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.stage: All his love bursting out into his face and into his voice, cries
sp.p: Blanche! Blanche!

div.stage: Leaning over her as if to protect her from her trouble and take her to his breast .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: Rising and looking straight into his eyes with a suddenly revealed great love in her own
sp.p: Ned! —

div.stage: They hold this position some moments, gazing into each other's eyes; then finally Warden makes a movement towards her, crying out more triumphantly, having read and realized her love for him .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Blanche!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: Moving a half step back from him .]
sp.p: No —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Look — look, it's beginning to snow!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I mean to speak of anything except what is in your thoughts at this moment! Help me not to forget that no matter what he has done, Dick is still my husband.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You don't know all he has done!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: How not "all"? What else? Where is he?

div.stage: With a sudden new alarm .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: He has left you.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Left me? —

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Mason is searching for him. He left a note at your house which Jess read; it was only one word "Good-by."

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Good-by!
[ Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance, coming quickly nearer .]
What does it mean? You're hiding something from me! Tell me what else you know?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: He left the house, but took something with him — something from a drawer in his room.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: After a second's pause she whispers .]
sp.p: His pistol?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Has he done it?

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: I don't know; I'm waiting word from Mason.

div.stage: The sleigh-bells stop .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: But we can't wait here doing nothing; we must go, too!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Mason is doing all that can be done; we'd better wait here.

div.stage: He takes her hand in sympathy, but without suggesting the passion of a few moments before . Sterling enters hurriedly Left. He is wild with drink and jealousy .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Drop my wife's hand!

div.stage: They turn in great surprise .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Dick!

div.stage: Fright at his appearance is mingled with her surprise .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.stage: At the same time as Blanche
sp.p: Sterling!

div.stage: They do not drop hands .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p:
Drop my wife's hand!
[ They do so quickly, not understanding yet .]
So I've caught you!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Caught us!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Yes, I had my suspicions roused some time ago!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I could go to the devil — what did you two care! I could go to State's Prison! All the better — out of your way!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You're speaking like a madman!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p:
I went back to my house this morning; my wife was gone — no message left where to! But I questioned the servant. She'd driven here! Why? Ha!
[ A bitter half laugh; he turns to Blanche .]
You've come here once too often!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Sterling!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.stage: To Warden , but ignoring his exclamation
sp.p: Then I went to your house. They knew where you'd gone! You ought to train your servants better! Both here!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: If you're not careful, I'll ram your insinuations down your throat.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: "Insinuations?" I've caught you! I make no " insinuations ." I tell you both you're caught! You're my wife's lover, and she's your damned mis —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Don't you finish!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Sh! — for Heaven's sake!
[ To Warden .]
Let him alone; I'm not afraid of what he says.

div.stage: Warden leaves Sterling .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: No, you never were a liar, I'll give you credit for that, — so confess the truth — you're his —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Listen! And you shall have the truth if you want it! These years that he's been befriending me I never dreamed of loving him nor thought of his loving me.
[ Dick sneers .]
Wait! No, not even the day my father was buried, when I learned outright you were dishonest!

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
What I say — I learned it then from a paper of my father's. I shouldn't have kept my knowledge to myself — I see that now; but I did, for your sake, not for love of you — the love went for good that day. But here, a moment ago, I realized
for the first time that my old friend did love me, love me with an ideal devotion the noblest woman in the world might be proud of! I didn't tell him then I loved him, but now I take this chance, I take it gladly before you! — forced by you! I tell him now, what perhaps he has already guessed, I love him with all my heart — I love him! I love him !

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Damn you both! then it's the end of me!

div.stage: He pulls out a pistol and tries to put it to his temple .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Ned!

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.stage: Seizes Sterling , catches his arm, and wrenches the pistol from him
sp.p: So that's what you planned to do, is it — make a wretched scene like that?

div.stage: It begins to snow more heavily .

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: Why did you stop me? I'm better out of the world. I'm crazy with shame. First I disgraced and now I've insulted — degraded — the only living thing I care for, — that's my wife.

div.stage: A moment's pause .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Come back to the house. Mr. Mason is looking for you; he has something to tell you.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p: I know — more bad news.

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No, good.

sp.speaker: Sterling .
sp.p:
Good!
[ Starting to go, he turns at the porch .]
I want you to know that I know I'm a rotten beast.

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You're going back home?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
" Home! "
[ With a faint smile .]
I should hardly call it that.

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: You're not afraid?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Oh, no! And my boy's there.

div.stage: The thick falling snow almost hides them, but they are unconscious of it .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Wait; we'll see — we'll see — let it be something we could never regret. Good-by, Ned.

div.stage: Giving him her hand .

sp.speaker: Warden .
sp.p: Good-by, Blanche.

div.stage: Kissing her hand very tenderly and almost with a certain kind of awe, as
The Curtain Slowly Falls

div.head: ACT IV
div.stage: The following morning; at the Sterlings '; the library; a warm, livable, and lovable room, full of pictures, photographs, and books; mistletoe and holly decorate everywhere. In the bow-window at back there is a large bird-cage with half a dozen birds in it. The furniture is comfortable and heavily upholstered. At Left there is a fireplace with logs ready, but the fire is not lit. There a big table near the centre, full of magazines, illustrated papers, and books. A big arm-chair is beside the table, and other chairs conversationally close. There is a table near the door at Right, piled with Christmas gifts, still wrapped in white paper; they are tied with many colored ribbons and bunches of holly. There are doors Right and Left. After the curtain rises on an empty stage , Ruth enters quickly; while she has her buoyant manner, she is, of course, more serious than usual. She carries a bunch of fresh violets in her hand. She looks about the room with a sort of curiosity. She is waiting for some one to appear. She takes up a silver-framed photograph of her brother which stands on a table and speaks aloud to it .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p:
I'm glad you're spared this.
[ With a long-drawn breath she places the photograph back upon the table and turns to greet Blanche , who comes in Right .]
Good morning, my dear.

div.stage: She kisses her .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
Good morning. You've had my note?
[ Ruth nods .]
Thank you. I wanted to
see you before I saw any one else. You must help me decide, only you can.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Have you seen your husband this morning?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: No. He sent word he was feeling ill, but would like to see me when I was willing.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: And you?

div.stage: They sit near each other .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I don't want to talk with him till I see more clearly what I am going to do.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Mr. Warden told me last night all that happened at "The Hermitage." But on your ride home with Dick?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p:
We never spoke.
[ She rises .]
Aunt Ruth, I am going to leave him.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: Why not? Everybody does.

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: That's just it. Be somebody! Don't do the easy, weak thing. Be strong; be an example to other women. Heaven knows it's time they had one!

div.stage: Mrs. Hunter enters Right . Blanche meets her .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Good morning, my poor dear.

div.stage: Going to kiss Blanche .

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.stage: Taking Mrs. Hunter's hand and not kissing her
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p: Clara's gone upstairs to see little Richard. Good morning, Ruth.

div.stage: She adds this with a manner of being on the defensive .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.stage: Sitting by the table and looking at the picture papers
sp.p: Isn't it awful! What are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Blanche .
sp.p: I don't know yet, mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hunter .
sp.p:
Don't know? Absolute divorce — no legal separation!
[ To Ruth .]
We're staying at the Waldorf.

div.stage: Blanche sits discouragedly on the sofa .

sp.speaker: Ruth .
sp.p: I shall advise against, and do everything in my power to prevent, Blanche's getting a divorce!
